segments.en: Numbered Discourses 4
4. Situations
38. Withdrawn
“Mendicants, a mendicant has eliminated idiosyncratic interpretations of the truth, has totally given up searching, has stilled the physical process, and is said to be ‘withdrawn’.
And how has a mendicant eliminated idiosyncratic interpretations of the truth?

segments.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno yāni tāni puthusamaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ puthupaccekasaccāni, seyyathidaṃ—
segments.en: Different ascetics and brahmins have different idiosyncratic interpretations of the truth. For example:

segments.pli: sassato lokoti vā, asassato lokoti vā, antavā lokoti vā, anantavā lokoti vā, taṃ jīvaṃ taṃ sarīranti vā, aññaṃ jīvaṃ aññaṃ sarīranti vā, hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇāti vā, na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇāti vā, hoti ca na ca hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇāti vā, neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇāti vā;
segments.en: the world is eternal, or not eternal, or finite, or infinite; the soul and the body are the same thing, or they are different things; after death, a Realized One exists, or doesn’t exist, or both exists and doesn’t exist, or neither exists nor doesn’t exist.

segments.pli: sabbāni tāni nuṇṇāni honti panuṇṇāni cattāni vantāni muttāni pahīnāni paṭinissaṭṭhāni.
segments.en: A mendicant has dispelled, eliminated, thrown out, rejected, let go of, given up, and relinquished all these.

segments.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu panuṇṇapaccekasacco hoti.
segments.en: That’s how a mendicant has eliminated idiosyncratic interpretations of the truth.
And how has a mendicant totally given up searching?

segments.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno kāmesanā pahīnā hoti, bhavesanā pahīnā hoti, brahmacariyesanā paṭippassaddhā.
segments.en: It’s when they’ve given up searching for sensual pleasures, for continued existence, and for a spiritual path.

segments.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu samavayasaṭṭhesano hoti.
segments.en: That’s how a mendicant has totally given up searching.
And how has a mendicant stilled the physical process?

segments.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā pubbeva somanassadomanassānaṃ atthaṅgamā adukkhamasukhaṃ upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṃ catutthaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.
segments.en: It’s when, giving up pleasure and pain, and ending former happiness and sadness, they enter and remain in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness.

segments.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu passaddhakāyasaṅkhāro hoti.
segments.en: That’s how a mendicant has stilled the physical process.
And how is a mendicant withdrawn?

segments.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno asmimāno pahīno hoti ucchinnamūlo tālāvatthukato anabhāvaṅkato āyatiṃ anuppādadhammo.
segments.en: It’s when they’ve given up the conceit ‘I am’, cut it off at the root, made it like a palm stump, obliterated it, so it’s unable to arise in the future.

segments.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu patilīno hoti.
segments.en: That’s how a mendicant is withdrawn.

segments.pli: Panuṇṇapaccekasacco, bhikkhave, bhikkhu ‘samavayasaṭṭhesano passaddhakāyasaṅkhāro patilīno’ti vuccatīti.
segments.en: A mendicant has eliminated idiosyncratic interpretations of the truth, has totally given up searching, has stilled the physical process, and is said to be ‘withdrawn’.
The search for sensual pleasures, for a good rebirth,
together with the search for a spiritual path;
holding tight to the notion ‘this is the truth’,
and the mass of grounds for views.
For one detached from all lusts,
freed by the ending of craving,
searching has been relinquished,
and viewpoints eradicated.
That mendicant is peaceful and mindful,
a tranquil champion.
And when they’re awakened by comprehending conceit,
they’re called ‘withdrawn’.”
